projects.name: Stages of Parkinson's Disease Detection with mobile phone video recordings
projects.summary: Parkinson's Disease diagnosis requires clinical assessments that may not be frequent enough to track its progression. This project aims to develop a machine learning pipeline for the detection and staging of Parkinson's disease using video recordings captured on mobile phones.

projects.name: Subsecond Animal Behavior Embeddings classification with Variational Autoencoders
projects.summary: Ethology studies heavily rely on human labeling of the data. This project improves the algorithm of an unsupervised learning model that embeds subsecond animal behavior (TREBA) that allows interpretable clustering of mice behaviors.

projects.name: The emergent effects of lexical and phonemic bias in automated speech recognition models
projects.summary: Human demonstrates lexical bias when listening to ambiguous words. This has been argued to be a top-down modulation in human brain. We investigated if this phenomenon is also present in automated speech recognition models, which is trained through a bottom-up, feedforward architecture.

publications.name: Active Dissociation of Intracortical Spiking and High Gamma Activity
publications.summary: Developed neurofeedback brain machine interfaces on primates in order to dissociate two highly correlated neural signals (spiking and high gamma activity), providing insight into brain machine interfaces signal sources.

publications.name: Decoding Speech Intent from Non-Frontal Cortical Areas
publications.summary: Neural signals in the temporal and parietal cortices contain distributed, causally decodable information about speech intent prior to voice onset, offering new avenues to improve speech brainâ€“machine interfaces and extend them to patients with frontal lobe damage.

publications.name: Visual Identification of Conspecifics Shapes Social Behavior in Mice
publications.summary: This study demonstrates that mice use visual cues to recognize the sex and identity of other mice, revealing an overlooked but important role of vision in shaping social interactions.

publications.name: From Receptive to Perceptive Fields: Size-Dependent Asymmetries in Both Negative Afterimages and Subcortical On and Off Post-Stimulus Responses
publications.summary: Modeling revealed that size-dependent antagonism in subcortical ON/OFF cells drives stronger, longer-lasting negative afterimages for dark versus bright stimuli.
